text:
I disagree. You can never let a person go or forget them no matter how much time passes if you really love them. But if you're referring to being obsessed with them after they passed, then that's another issue altogether. Being obsessed about anything in general is unhealthy. Having technology like this to occasionally check on their memories isn't so bad, though. People have videos, pictures and voice recordings of people for ages now. So it's not too far off from any of these other things. The difference of course is interacting, but there's video games today which takes plenty of people's likeness in these games to interact with them, of course, most of these games having famous people instead.

You can let go how much or little you want though. Everyone's brain works differently.

text:
I've just seen a korean movie on Netflix called "Wonderland". It's about advanced A.I. technology where you can transfer your memories into A.I. before you die. You can live in that "Wonderland" as anything you want, and you can communicate with your family through video calls. But your family has to pay continuously for your living expenses while you're in the simulation. You also won't realize you're dead, or the simulation would break. Once your family stops paying, they'll just delete "you". The upside is, ot can help a grieving family. And the downside is the predatory paying system. And also the dilemma of the reality that the person you love has actually gone and you can never see them again, touch & hug them in real life..

This news right here feels like a beginning towards that gloomy future, I'm afraid...

text: What I would have given to have this when I lost my brother 14 yrs ago‚Ä¶.But given my mental state during those first few yrs because of the sudden loss, I dont think I‚Äôd be where I am today if I‚Äôd had it. @ that time I was so vulnerable & desperate for him to just be alive, I think I‚Äôd have taken it in a very unhealthy direction & convinced myself it was him. But I think it‚Äôs a wonderful tool for those who can actually keep their clarity intact despite their grief. Though I‚Äôm sure the percentage of those ppl would be very small in comparison to the rest , if how I felt is anywhere near a typical reaction to losing a loved one.  It would however be nice to have now & especially for his youngest daughter who was only 4 yrs old when he died to hear his voice & get a sense of who he was.  It‚Äôs very hard to ‚Äòexplain‚Äô his sense of humor etc and I‚Äôd love for her to know those things about him that we all loved. He is essentially a stranger to her despite all the memories I have about their time together -she has nothing. Her sisters would have loved a message like this n their wedding days too, I‚Äôm sure. The pain is unbearable when loosing the ones close to you- I have lost my parents and my closest family and friends- but , when I was a child I thought of this in my mind actually- to maybe reconstruct their voice so I could hear them again- however, No Machine ever can replace your loved one- you are giving the energy into an object and making it an idol - one might get attached or start to believe they are actually talking to their dead loved one- as much as it hurts - this isn‚Äôt healthy to grieve (and I do understand- people grieve differently) but, at this point it seems like her parents are in deep denial- and this isn‚Äôt healthy. And as AI advances- they might want to make a silicone (robot) version and it will just keep getting worse. This isn‚Äôt their daughter and they need to let her RIP. Also, I might add that dark entities in this world look for bodies (whether that be Dolls- Statues- People if they let that portal open ) one should let them be. I do pray for them and hope they find comfort but this isn‚Äôt it. They should remember the good times- but, no one can be Creator for there is Only One and That‚Äôs God himself.

Such behavior shouldn‚Äôt be encouraged- but rather seek therapy to help these parents get through the pain of their loss of their dear daughter

text: I think this technology could be really helpful for people who didn't get closure when their loved one passed away. People who experience the sudden and/or unexpected death of a loved one frequently suffer because they didn't get to say goodbye or tie up loose ends, and so this technology could really help them work through that trauma during the grieving process. Otherwise, I feel that this technology could really be harmful if it is used to deny the fact that someone is gone. Everybody dies, we all lose people we love. That must be accepted whether or not we like it. So, helpful in specific cases, creepy and harmful in a lot of cases.

text: Folks, I know this isn't "real", but let me tell you, for many, they will find comfort in this.  This is only scratching the surface. You'll be able to re-create anyone in a fantasy virtual reality and interact with them daily, watch them grow up, attend their graduations, wedding, etc.  You'll be able to go on trips with them and have lunch dates, they'll be with you in the form of holograms, ai apps on your phone calling you at random times of the week to talk, and once the holodeck becomes reality, you'll be able to physically touch them and give them a hug.  It's an illusion and fantasy that plays on your emotions and mind, but sometimes that's a better relief than to face the pain and reality of being alone.   This will also be available for pets called NU-PET or NEX-PET.  You'll see.

text: I feel like this can't be healthy overall. While AI might offer temporary comfort by allowing continued interaction with a dead loved one, it could be psychologically damaging by obstructing the natural grieving process, philosophically confusing by undermining the finality and meaning of death, and emotionally unfulfilling due to its artificial nature. Embracing death as part of the human condition is essential for personal growth and acceptance, and AI simulations risk interfering with this profound, albeit painful, process.

text: The survivors should be allowed to grieve however way is possible.  I lost my mother in a car accident.  Instead of being by her side and holding her hand I was busy recording the moment, for the rest of my family that were not there.  I deeply regret doing that and not holding her hand, because I didn‚Äôt know she was dying.  I was just standing back as that is what the officer told me to do.  As well, I wish I could ask my mother for advice on family matters as well as gardening.  It wouldn‚Äôt matter if it was useful advice.  Just to get it would be soothing.  As well, I was born on her birthday, so celebrating my birthday seems unnatural without her here to celebrate it with me.  Just getting a text message wishing me a happy birthday would be great!  Even using AI for a pet would be helpful.  My cat of over 10 years didn‚Äôt come home one night and I knew he would never be coming home again.  I am sure he met up with a coyote. Six months later his companion cat, my pet of 4 years, also didn‚Äôt come home.  Coyote again.  It would be nice to see them both again.
